This course was pretty much terrible. The lectures were basically worthless because Nick moves through the material too quickly and skips the mathematically rigorous steps, assuming that everyone understands what is going on. His course notes are so extraordinarily cursory that they're basically worthless as well. The recommended textbook from Vaughn is awful. We had to use other textbooks and self-study, which made it even more frustrating that I wasted all of my time in class. If I could take this course again, I would have never gone to class a single day and just did the homeworks. These homeworks took nearly double the length of time that our QM/CM homework sets took...

The course could be improved by having a different person design and teach it.

I thought that the structure of the course was fairly cohesive, although many of the lectures were difficult to understand if you had not previously taken a class on the topic. Additionally, some of the concepts in the homework were not addressed until the day that the homework was due, which made the homework much more difficult. The exams were very fair, though, and very clearly tested material that was emphasized both in the lectures and in the homework.

This course straddles the boundary between math and applied math.  As such there is an uneven distribution of emphasis on rigorous proof (e.g. we spend a great deal of time on proof in the beginning of the course, but very little at the end).  This has the effect of our spending more time on things most of us find intuitive (e.g. manipulating matrices) and less on brand-new material (Laplace's method for integral approximation).
The instructor should stress less on linear algebra. Few of the audience will have the chance to apply this part of the knowledge to this level.
Less time on linear algebra, more time on complex analysis and asymptotics of differential equations.
